This should probably be in a separate thread, but I'll post it anyway.. =

One of the major issues I have with the RDF model is that it's
objectiv=
e seems to be to make every resource a possible 'starting
point' - i.e. it =
tries to provide a model for 'bootstrapping' a
machine client into a contex=
t for any 'generic' resource on the web.
We don't have this in REST, instea=
d we have a limited set of entry
points and from then on discovery/traversa=
l of an application at run
time. This means there's a tonne of features (re=
ad: bloat) and
assumptions that are inherent to implementations like RDFa w=
hich, from
a REST pov, are at best distracting and at worst actually corros=
ive to
the kinds of behaviours we are trying to invoke when designing RESTf=
ul
hypertext applications.

REST's perspective on semantics seems to be bas=
ed on a relational
theory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_theory) =
whereas RDF's
perspective seems to be based on more of an absolute theory
(=
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_theory). I believe this
difference  i=
s at the root of the apparent schism between REST and RDF
and I can't find =
a way to reconcile this, so I avoid RDF.

I still wanted a generic media ty=
pe but without the RDF baggage, so
that's why I created HAL. Some other peo=
ple seem to prefer it too.
